Enhancement of Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts through control of pH and oxygen mobility during their preparation Ki Bok Nam Dong Ho Kim Sung Chang Hong ⁎ Department of Environmental Energy Engineering, Graduate School of Kyonggi University, 94-6 San, Iui-dong, Youngtong-ku, Suwon-si, Gyeonggi-do, 443-760, Republic of Korea Department of Environmental Energy Engineering Graduate School of Kyonggi University 94-6 San, Iui-dong, Youngtong-ku Suwon-si Gyeonggi-do 443-760 Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The purpose of this study is to investigate the effects of pH control on the oxidation state and oxygen storage capacity of catalysts, and the correlation with low-temperature selective catalytic reduction (SCR) activities using Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts. The activity of the catalysts showed increases in low-temperature SCR reaction activity at (120–180) °C, when the pH of the slurry of active metal and support TiO2 was controlled to low levels during the preparation of Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts. To characterize these catalysts, NH3-TPD, FT-IR DRIFT, XPS, and O2-chemisorption were analyzed. In the DRIFT experiment using FT-IR, the NH3 adsorption on acid sites of the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts, which exhibited excellent reaction activity in the SCR reaction, was increased, compared with those of the Mn/Ce/Ti catalysts. In particular, the NH4 + adsorbed on Brønsted acid site was greatly increased. When the adsorbed NH3 was reacted with injected NO + O2, the adsorbed NH3 species was rapidly decreased on Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts whose pH was controlled to low levels, and the reaction rate was greatly increased. According to XPS analysis, the increase of the O2 storage capacity of the catalyst is due to the decrease of the lattice oxygen present on the surface, and the increase of adsorbed oxygen species as the nonstoichiometric species Ce3+ increases. In addition, the O2-chemisorption showed that oxygen mobility was increased in the catalysts whose pH was controlled to low levels. These results indicate that oxygen mobility was increased due to the increases in the adsorbed oxygen species, which was found by XPS analysis. Therefore, the control of pH in the preparation of Mn catalyst increases the Brønsted acid site on the catalyst surface and increases oxygen mobility, due to the increase of adsorbed oxygen species, resulting in an increase in the SCR activity. Keywords Mn/Ce/W/Ti Oxalic acid Low-temperature SCR Oxygen storage capacity Valance state Oxidation ability 1 Introduction As nitrogen oxides (NOx) are a gaseous substance that has harmful effects on the environment and human body by causing smog and acid rain, it is required to remove them. In particular, nitrogen oxides result from the combustion of fossil fuels used as fuels for internal and external combustion engines being used in industrial facilities, automobiles, and ships [1]. Emissions of nitrogen oxides inevitably occur during production activities and industrial development, but there is a growing demand for decreasing emissions of nitrogen oxides at national levels rather than individual, household and company levels at the same time. As environmental laws and regulations on emission sources have been strengthened, there is a growing demand for the technology to remove nitrogen oxides in order to actively cope with the strictly enhanced environmental regulations in the future. For this reason, it has been known that a selective catalytic reduction (SCR) method using NH3 as a reducing agent is the most effective way to remove nitrogen oxides [2]. This method degrades nitrogen oxides into N2 and H2O which are harmless to the human body by using the catalyst after NH3 is injected as a reducing agent into the gas including nitrogen oxides [3]: (1) 4NO + 4NH3 + O2 → 4N2 + 6H2O V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalysts are currently used as commercial catalysts commonly used in SCR facilities. Although the V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst has some advantages such as wide ranges of operating temperatures and durability against sulfur [4,5]. The reaction heat of 300 °C or more is required to show the activity and durability necessary for the applications such as the incineration facilities and the power plant. However, it causes various problems such as toxicity of vanadium volatilized at high temperatures[6]. Some studies using various transition metals have been actively conducted in order to overcome the drawbacks of the V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst [7–9]. Recently, the installation position of SCR unit tends to be shifted into the back-end of FGD, which decreases the reaction temperature [10]. In the case of existing industrial boilers, there is no space for installing the SCR due to its narrow space. Thus, it is possible to limitedly install the system in a low-temperature range of 200 °C or lower after the burner [11]. In recent years, the heat loss is reduced due to the increases in thermal efficiency of external and internal combustion engines, and the SCR operating temperature has been gradually decreasing as the temperature of exhaust gas is being lowered [12]. Therefore, it is required to have the technology of the catalyst with decreasing temperature of the exhaust gas. The low-temperature catalysts have been studied by using various transition metals such as Mn, Cu, Fe, and Co as the support of TiO2, SiO2, and Al2O3. Among the various SCR transition metals, Mn is more positively charged than other neighboring atoms and its reactivity is superior to that of other atoms. Thus, it is more frequently used as a transition metal of SCR catalyst. In particular, as the SCR reaction activity is high at 200 °C or lower, many researchers are conducting the studies by using various methods. Various studies on Mn support catalysts using pure MnOx [13,14], binding of Mn with metal oxides (Mn-CeO2, Mn-FeOx etc.) [15,16], and binding with various supports such as Mn, TiO2, and Al2O3 are actively being conducted in the area of low-temperature SCR [17]. Among them, the Mn/TiO2 catalyst has high dispersion of TiO2 which is the support, durability against SO2 and structural strength. Thus, it exhibits high activities among Mn-based catalysts being used at low temperature [18,19], and it is being applied in various areas. Smirniotis et al. [20] studied low-temperature SCR reaction activity of Mn/TiO2 depending on various phases of TiO2 and found that the reaction activity was determined by the surface area, the Lewis acidity and the Mn surface concentration of TiO2. Kim et al. [21] found that the Mn valence state on the catalyst surface affected the catalytic activity depending on the pH of TiO2. Li et al. [22] prepared Mn/TiO2 catalysts using manganese nitrate and manganese acetate and found that manganese nitrate had more excellent low-temperature SCR activity than manganese acetate. Jiang et al. [23] studied the effects of the preparation methods such as sol-gel method, impregnation method and co-precipitation method on the activities of the catalyst when preparing the Mn/TiO2 catalyst. They found that the sol-gel method exhibited the best low-temperature SCR reaction activity. Various studies are being conducted on the effects of the physicochemical properties of TiO2 support, properties of Mn precursors and various preparation methods on low-temperature SCR reaction activities of Mn/TiO2 catalyst. In recent years, studies have been focused on increases in the activity of Mn/TiO2 catalyst by adding a co-catalyst. For example, studies have been conducted on Mn-Ce/TiO2 [24], Mn-Fe/TiO2 [25], and Mn-Ni/TiO2 [26] & Mn-Y/TiO2 [27]. Lee et al [24] claimed that catalyst specific surface area and Mn valence state were increased with the addition of Ce to the Mn/TiO2 catalyst, and activities were increased due to the increase in acid site. Shen et al. [25] found that dispersion of transition metals on the catalyst surface was increased with the addition of Fe and reaction activities were increased with enhanced valence state and increased surface adsorption oxygen species. In addition, all above-mentioned transition metals such as Ni and Y were added to the Mn/TiO2 catalyst to enhance the reaction activities with increases in redox characteristics of the catalyst and surface oxygen species. According to various studies, the low-temperature SCR reaction activity of the Mn-based catalysts is most affected by the valence state and this property is determined by the characteristics of the catalyst support, the preparation method, and the addition of the co-catalyst. However, the study on the effects of preparation methods was limited to the single bond between the transition metal, Mn, and the support TiO2. Recent studies on low-temperature SCR catalysts have focused on Mn-based catalysts using supports added with various co-catalysts. The reason is believed to cope with the increasingly stringent environmental regulations and to expand the applications. Therefore, it is required to study the catalysts of composite compounds applying Mn of various composite supports in order to show the performance which satisfies the enhanced regulations in the future. This study has been based on the results of existing studies on Mn catalysts using the Ce/W/Ti support [28]. The purpose of this study is to check the changes in valence state and adsorption characteristics of the catalysts when pH is controlled during catalyst preparation and to examine the low-temperature SCR activities. In order to achieve this purpose described above, a Mn-based catalyst with different characteristics was prepared under different pH conditions by using a wet impregnation method. Various physical and chemical properties of the corresponding catalysts such as valence state and redox characteristics were analyzed using various physicochemical techniques such as temperature-programmed desorption (TPD), (DRIFT) and XPS. 2 Experiments 2.1 Preparation method of catalysts The Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst to be used in this study was prepared by a wet impregnation method, and the manufacturing method was divided into two steps, as follows. The reagents used in this study were Anatase-type TiO2 (MC-50, Ishiara Sangyo Kaisha, Ltd.), Manganese(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Mn(NO3O2∙6H2O, Aldrich Chemical Co.), Cerium(III) nitrate, ammonium metatungstate hydrate ((NH4)6H2W12O40, Aldrich Co.), and Oxalic acid dehydrate (C2H2O4, Aldrich Co.). Prior to the preparation of the catalyst, saturated oxalic acid solution was prepared by dissolving 14.3 g oxalic acid dehydrate in 100 mL distilled water as a solution to control pH (Oxalic acid solubility in water = 143 g/L at 25 °C). First, the calculated amounts of cerium(III) nitrate (4 wt.% Ce) and tungsten (5 wt.% W) were immersed in distilled H2O. After TiO2 and ceria were mixed with tungsten solution, the slurry was stirred for 1 h. Then, the water was removed at 70 °C through evaporation, and residual water was removed in a dry oven at 103 °C. After that, the Ce/W/Ti support was prepared by calcination in the air atmosphere at 400 °C for 4 h. Second, the amount of Manganese(II) nitrate hexahydrate (20 wt.% Mn) was calculated based on the prepared Ce/W/Ti support, and was then immersed in distilled water. After the Mn solution was mixed with the Ce/W/Ti support, it was stirred to make slurry for 1 h. After the pH of the slurry was controlled to 2.5 or 1.7 using the previously prepared oxalic acid solution (pH of slurry without the pH adjustment = 3.5), it was further stirred for 1 h. Water was then removed using evaporation at 70 °C, and a dry oven at 103 °C. The catalysts were calcined in air for 4 h at 400 °C. 2.2 Catalytic reaction The SCR activity measurements were carried out in a fixed-bed quartz reactor (inner diameter 8 mm). The reactant gases were fed into the reactor using a mass flow controller (MKS Co.). The typical reactant gas composition was as follows: 200 ppm NO, 200 ppm NH3, 8 vol% O2, and 8 vol% H2O in N2. For each test, 0.6 g of catalyst (40–50 mesh, 1.2 cc) was used. The total flow rate was 600 cc/min, corresponding to a space velocity of 30,000 h−1. The composition of the feed gases and the effluent streams were continuously monitored online using non-dispersive infrared gas analyzers (ZKJ-2, Fuji Electric Co. for NO/NO2 and an Ultramat 6, Siemens Co., for N2O). Water in all gases was removed through the chiller, before entering the analyzer. The NOx conversion and N2 selectivity were calculated from the concentrations of the gases at steady state, according to the following equation: (2) N O x c o n v e r s i o n % = N O i n - N O + N O 2 o u t N O i n × 100 (3) N 2 s e l e c t i v i t y % = N O i n + [ N H 3 ] i n - N O 2 o u t - 2 [ N 2 O ] o u t N O i n + [ N H 3 ] i n × 100 2.3 Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) The specific surface area of the catalyst was measured using the ASAP 2010C model of Micromeritics Co. and the BET(Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) equation. All samples were analyzed after removing gas from vacuum for 110 °C to 3–5 hours. 2.4 X-ray fluorescence (XRF) X-ray fluorescence (XRF) analysis quantified material composition of the catalysts using ZSX Primus(Rigaku). 2.5 In situ DRIFTS studies This study used an in situ DRIFTs analysis performed by FT-IR (Nicolet iS10, Thermo Co.). A DiffuseIR(DR) 400 accessory (PIKE technologies Co.) was used for the analysis of the solid reflectance. The CaF2 window was used as a plate for the DR measurement, and spectra were collected using a mercury cadmium telluride (MCT) detector. All of the catalysts used for this analysis were ground using a rod in the sample pan of the in situ chamber (PIKE technologies Co.) with an installed temperature controller. To prevent the influence of moisture and impurities, the sample was preprocessed with N2 at a rate of 100 cc/min at 300 °C for 1 h. Then, the spectra of the catalyst were collected by measuring the single-beam spectrum of the preprocessed sample as background, and all analyses were performed by auto scanning at a resolution of 4 cm−1. The Absorbance IR spectra were recorded bya Nicolet Nexus spectrometry (Model Magna IR 550 II) equipped with a liquid nitrogen cooled MCT detector that collected 32 scans with a spectral resolution of 4 cm−1. 2.6 NH3 temperature –programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was carried out to evaluate the adsorption capacity of the catalyst. This measurement was carried out with 0.3 g samples of the catalysts. Prior to the TPD measurements, the catalysts were pretreated at 300 °C for 30 min while in a 50 cc/min flow of 5% O2/He. Then the samples were cooled to 50 °C, and were then treated with 1% NH3/Ar for 1 h. Before the TPD experiments, the NH3 was purged for 1 h with Ar. During the TPD experiments, the quantity of NH3 (NH3; m/e = 15) was continuously monitored by a quadrupole mass spectrometer (QMS 422), while the temperature was increased to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. 2.7 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) An Escalab 210 (VG Scientific) instrument was used in this study. The excitation source was monochromatic Al-K (1486.6 eV) radiation. After water was completely removed from the sample (before SCR reaction) by drying at 100 °C for 24 h, the catalysts were analyzed without surface sputtering or etching, so that the degree of vacuum in the XPS equipment was maintained at (10−6) Pa. XPS PEAK software (ver. 4.1) was used to analyze spectra. The intensities were estimated by integration of each peak, subtraction of the Shirley background, and fitting of the experimental curve to combinations of Lorentzian and Gaussian lines of various proportions. All binding energies were normalized by the C 1 s line at 284.6 eV. The binding energy values were measured with a precision of ± 0.3 eV. 2.8 O2-chemisorption O2-chemisorption was carried out to evaluate the oxygen mobility capacity of the catalyst. Experiments were conducted using Auto Chem II 2920 (Micrometrics) connected to a Cirrus Mass Spectrometer (MKS Instruments, (1–300) amu). Samples of ∼200 mg were sandwiched between two layers of quartz wool, and subjected to cleaning step in air for 30 min at the sample calcination temperature, and then subjected to a reduction step with 10% H2/N2 gas at 160 °C for 30 min (reaction temperature). Afterwards, the O2 pulses were introduced at 160 °C. The m/e 32 signal was continuously monitored by mass spectrometry, until there was no variation between two consecutive peaks. Experimental result integration is performed by an automated software provided with the instrument. It is named "saturation peak" when there is no further peak change. Peak changes ( Δ Area) are calculated using each peak pulse area and saturation peak. Then use peak changes( Δ Area) to calculate the oxygen gas consumption. Calculate the final oxygen consumption by summing all the calculated amounts for each pulse. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity The effect of pH on the selective catalytic reduction activity of the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts was evaluated. The composition of the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst used in the experiment and the surface area (BET) of each catalyst are shown in Table 1 . Experimental results show no change in catalyst content or BET due to pH control. Therefore, it can be seen that there is no influence of the loss due to elution due to the pH adjustment of the active metal during the production of the catalyst. Fig. 1 shows that the NOx conversion activity was determined using Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 3.5), Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 2.5), and Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 1.7) at (120–400) °C using a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 60,000 h−1. The activities of Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 3.5), Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 2.5), and Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 1.7) catalysts showed ∼90% NOx conversion rate at 180 °C. The differences in activities of the three catalysts were less than 3%. However, the width of decrease in the efficiency of Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 2.5) and Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 1.7) catalysts, which were prepared through control of pH, was reduced; while the reaction activity of Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 3.5) catalysts, whose pH was not controlled, sharply decreased. In particular, the reaction activity of Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 3.5) and Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 1.7) catalysts at 140 °C was (43 and 79) %, respectively. The difference in activity was up to 36%. Therefore, it was found that the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst whose pH was controlled had excellent effects on low-temperature reaction activity promotion. However, the reaction activity of Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 3.5) catalysts was 95% at 180 °C or more. The NOx conversion rate of the Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 2.5) and Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 1.7) catalysts was decreased to (87 and 95) % by (8 and 10) %, respectively. This decrease in activity was more apparent at high temperatures above 200 °C. In addition, the activity of Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 3.5) decreased at temperatures above 250 °C. This decrease in activity is thought to be due to an abrupt increase in the amount of N2O generated at temperatures above 180 °C, as shown in Fig. 1. Especially, the amount of N2O produced in Mn/Ce/W/Ti which pH was controlled to low levels, was dramatically increased when temperatures above 180 °C. 3.2 Characterization of the catalysts 3.2.1 XPS characterization The valence state of the metals added to the catalyst has been reported to be a factor that greatly affects the SCR reaction activity [29,30]. The catalytic reaction is dynamic and the state of the surface before and during the reaction may be different. However, as the basic reaction of the SCR catalyst proceeds to a cycle reaction of reduction and oxidation, the initial state of the catalyst can also be used as a basis for determining the catalytic reaction. In particular, Mn added as an active metal and Ce added as a co-catalyst exhibit various valence states, and thus various reaction characteristics are shown. First, Mn has various valence states of MnO2, Mn2O3 Mn3O4, and Mn5O5, and its SCR reactivity varies, depending on the valence state. In particular, the oxygen transfer ability of MnO2 (Mn4+) is superior to that of the other Mn valence states (Mn2O3, Mn3O4, and Mn5O8), and the reaction of oxidation/reduction cycles is excellent. Thus, it is favorable to SCR reaction [31]. The valence states of these active metals have been reported to exhibit various oxidation states, depending on various conditions at the time of preparation [21,32]. In particular, the pH of the support used in the preparation of the catalysts has been reported to affect the valence state of Mn in the prepared catalyst [21]. In this study, XPS analysis was performed to examine the effect of pH of the aqueous slurry on the valence state of Mn during the preparation of catalysts. Fig. 2 shows the results. The valence state of Mn, in Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 3.2), Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 2.5), and Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 1.7) systems, having different activities, was measured. In addition, Table 2 shows the Mn4+/total Mn ratio depending on the slurry pH. Fig. 2 shows the XPS data, which reveals the Mn 2p peak in the profiles of Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 3.2), Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 2.5), and Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 1.7). The Mn 2p peak was fitted into sub-bands by searching for the optimum combination of Gaussian bands. The spectra of all the catalysts displayed three peaks with binding energies of (641.2, 642.2, and 644.5) eV, corresponding to Mn2O3, MnO2, and Mn-nitrate, respectively; the values are consistent with those reported in the literature [33]. The Mn-nitrate peak was produced by partial reaction in manganese nitrate precursor used in the preparation of catalysts, due to the low calcination temperatures [34]. The Mn4+ ratios of all catalysts were calculated as Mn4+/(Mn3++Mn4+). The ratio of Mn4+ was shown in the following order; Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 1.7) (47.53%) > Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 2.5) (43.76%) > Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 3.2) (41.79%). The ratio of Mn4+/(Mn3++Mn4+) in Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 3.2), whose pH was not controlled, was 41.79%. As pH was controlled to low levels, the ratio of Mn4+ was gradually increased to 43.76% (pH 2.5) and 47.53% (pH 1.7). The ratio of Mn4+/(Mn3++Mn4+) in various pH was the same order as that shown in the SCR reaction activity in Fig. 1. Therefore, this result showed enhancement, as the surface Mn4+ was active in the low temperature SCR reaction. However, it is difficult to explain the relatively great increase in low-temperature SCR reaction activity, and the decrease in the activity above 180 °C in proportion to the increase in the Mn4+ ratio. Therefore, although the Mn4+/(Mn3++Mn4+) ratio affects some activity promotion, it is difficult to consider it as a major factor for activity promotion. Next, Ce added as a co-catalyst was also reported to affect the SCR reaction depending on the oxidation state [28]. Thus, XPS analysis was performed to investigate the Ce valence state of the catalyst prepared in this study. Fig. 3 and Table 2 show the Ce3+/total Ce ratio depending on the slurry pH during the catalyst preparation. Fig. 3 shows the Ce 3d peaks in the XPS profiles of Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 3.5), Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 2.5), and Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 1.7). Fig. 3 shows that the Ce 3d peak was fitted into sub-bands by searching for the optimum combination of Gaussian bands. The sub-bands labeled u1 and v1 represent the 3d104f1 initial electronic state, corresponding to Ce3+, and the sub-bands labeled u, u2, u3, v, v2, and v3 represent the 3d104f0 state of Ce4+ [35]. Fig. 3 and Table 2 show that the Ce3+/total Ce ratio was higher with lower pH, as follows: Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 1.7) (25.63%) > Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 2.5) (18.99%) > Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 3.5) (12.40%). Catalysts with higher SCR efficiency showed the higher Ce3+ ratio. However, Ce XPS analysis lacks confidence in the measured values at low intensities. This is because of the low content of Ce. Therefore, this Ce valence state can explain the increase of Ce3+ more clearly by the relationship between Mn4+ ratio and the oxygen species described later. According to the literature, when Ce was added, an oxygen bridge (Mn–O–Ce) was formed by CeO2, and the bond between Mn and oxygen was strengthened. This oxygen bridge has a synergistic effect between Ce and Mn, and is known to promote the oxidation from Mn3+ to Mn4+ by Ce4+ as in (eq 3) [36]. (4) Mn2O3 + 2CeO2 → 2MnO2 + Ce2O3 Although the detailed mechanism of the reaction is not known, it has been reported to be related to the well-known oxygen storage function of CeO2 [37], and thus the increase of valence of Mn. When the pH is controlled during the preparation of the catalyst, the ratio of Mn4+ and Ce3+ increases. Thus, it can be hypothesized that the formation of the oxygen bridging bond is promoted. In addition, it has been reported that the oxidation of NO to NO2 is promoted in the SCR reaction when the Ce3+ species is generated, and thus fast SCR reaction of the catalysts is induced to promote the overall activity [38]. The increase in the ratio of nonstoichiometric Ce3+ species increases the oxygen vacancies of the catalyst, and thus increases the adsorbed oxygen species to increase the oxygen transport capacity. Based on these increases, the oxidizing power of the catalyst is increased. Therefore, the increase in the oxidizing characterizes of the catalyst increases the SCR reaction activity. In order to examine the oxygen, transfer capacity, O1 s analysis of Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 3.5), Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 2.5), and Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 1.7) catalysts, which could check the changes of adsorbed oxygen species, was performed. Fig. 4 and Table 2 show the results. The O1 s spectrum can be fitted to two peaks corresponding to various oxygen species, including chemical bonds. According to previous studies, the binding energy of (529.5–529.8) eV corresponds to the binding energy of lattice oxygen Oα, which is represented as O2− and O-. At a higher binding energy of (531.8–532.5) eV, the chemisorbed oxygen species appears, which is represented as Oβ [39,40]. Fig. 4 and Table 2 show that when the pH of the catalyst was controlled to low levels, the ratio of Oα corresponding to lattice oxygen was decreased, but the ratio of Oβ corresponding to chemisorbed species was increased from 29.60% (pH 3.5) to 34.68% (pH 2.5) and 35.36% (pH 1.7). The increase of adsorbed oxygen species induced the promotion of the SCR reaction activity through increases in the oxygen transfer capacity and oxidative ability in the SCR reaction. The adsorbed oxygen species and transport capacity of oxygen will be described in detail in a later section. 3.2.2 Adsorption characterization 3.2.2.1 NH3 adsorption characterization Through previous studies, we found that the adsorption capacity of NH3 on the surface of Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst increased, and that the inhibition of NOx species formation on the surface of the catalyst promoted the low-temperature SCR reaction activity [28,41]. It was found that adsorption capacity of the surface of catalyst and kinds of adsorption species were important factors affecting the low-temperature SCR reaction activity. Therefore, the experiment was conducted to examine the effects of pH control on the adsorption characteristics of the surface of the catalyst, during the preparation of Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst. In order to analyze the adsorption amount and adsorption intensity of NH3 on the surface of the catalyst, Temperature programmed desorption (TPD; NH3-TPD) experiment using NH3 was performed. Fig. 5 shows the results of the NH3-TPD test. As the pH of Mn/Ce/W/Ti was controlled to pH 3.5 (standard), pH 2.5, or pH 1.7, some adsorption amounts were increased, and NH3 desorption peaks were observed in the same pattern. The first and second peaks were detected at ((80–160) and (160–250)) °C, respectively. Various literatures have reported that desorption peaks of NH3 could be classified into two types, such as the Brønsted-acid site and Lewis-acid site. In general, the adsorption of NH3 contributes to the interaction between NH and vanadyl oxygen. In the case of the Brønsted-acid site with hydroxyl group, the hydroxyl group has a higher reactivity to ammonia adsorption and relatively weak adsorption intensity has been reported [33,42]. Therefore, the peak detected at (80–160) ° C is NH4+ adsorbed at the Brønsted-acid site of weak adsorption strength and the desorbed peak at (160–250) ° C is considered to be NH3 adsorbed at the Lewis acid site. Fig. 5 shows that the amount of adsorbed NH3 was increased with decreasing pH as follows: Mn/Ce/W/Ti pH 3.5 (1.00) < Mn/Ce/W/Ti pH 2.5 (1.36) < Mn/Ce/W/Ti pH 1.7 (1.79). In addition, desorption peaks of NH3 were increased at both low temperature ((80–160) °C), and high temperature ((160–250) °C). As the pH was lowered from (3.5 to 1.7), both Brønsted-site and Lewis-acid sites were increased. To further clarify the increases in these acid sites, the following NH3-DRIFT experiments were performed. The NH3 adsorption species on Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 3.5) and Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 1.7) at 160 °C were investigated by FT-IR spectroscopy. Before NH3 adsorption, the samples were pre-treatment at 300 °C in N2 for 1 h to remove other adsorbed species. After the sample was cooled to 160 °C at adsorption temperature, 1000 ppm NH3 was introduced at the temperature for 30 min. Fig. 6 shows that the peaks of adsorbed NH3 in Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 3.5) and Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 1.7) catalysts were detected at (1,438, 1535, 1600, 2808, 3,143, 3,245, and 3377) cm−1. Fig. 6 indicates coordinated NH3 species (1600, 3,143, 3,245, and 3377 cm−1), and NH4 + species (1,438, 1535 and 2808 cm−1) formed on Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 3.5) and Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 1.7) catalysts upon treatment with NH3 [43,44]. Among them, it has been found that the Lewis-acid site corresponding to 1600 cm−1 and the Brønsted-acid site corresponding to 1439 cm−1 were greatly increased in Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 1.7) catalyst. These results were inferred by comparing peak intensities using the maximum peak of the two catalysts, 3245 cm−1 (L). In the case of Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst, the intensities ratio of 1600/3245 was 0.84 and that of 1439/3245 was 0.74. In the Mn/Ce/W/Ti (B) catalyst, the intensities ratio of 1600/3245 is 0.91 and that of 1439/3245 is 0.87, thus confirming the increased intensities ratio. In addition, Brønsted-acid site corresponding to 2808 cm−1 was not observed in the Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 3.5) catalyst, but was observed in the Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 1.7) catalyst. These results indicate that the pH control of the catalyst affected the increases in the Lewis-acid site and the Brønsted-acid site on the surface of catalysts. In addition, negative peaks were detected at (1329 and 3637) cm−1, which was thought to be the −OH peak. These negative peaks were thought to be produced by consuming −OH on the surface, when NH3 was adsorbed in the form of NH4 + in the Brønsted-acid site. Thus, according to the results of the above NH3-TPD and NH3-DRIFT experiments, it was found that the Lewis-acid site and Brønsted-acid site on the surface of catalysts were substantially increased, and the adsorption amount of NH3 was increased with lowering pH. 3.2.2.2 NO adsorption characterization The previous experiments indicated that NO on the surface of the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts negatively affected the low-temperature SCR reaction [41]. Thus, in order to check the change of NO adsorption characteristics on the surface of Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 1.7) catalyst, NO adsorbed species on the Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 3.5), and Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 1.7) catalysts were investigated by NO-DRIFT. Before NO adsorption, the samples were treated in N2 at 300 °C for 30 min, to remove any adsorbed species. After the samples were cooled to 160 °C (temperature showing the biggest difference in efficiency), they were treated to 1000 ppm NO and 3% O2 on Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 3.5), and Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 1.7) at the same temperature, as shown in Fig. 7 . Several bands at (1242, 1,290, 1,487, 1540, 1582, 1606, and 1620) cm−1 were observed. The bands (1242 and 1606) cm−1 could be attributed to bridged nitrate [17]. The bands at (1,290, 1,487, and 1540) cm−1 can be assigned to monodentate nitrate [43]. The bands at 1582 cm−1 might be assigned to bidentate nitrate [43]. The bands at 1620 cm−1 could be assigned to the asymmetric frequency of gaseous NO2 molecules. Fig. 7 shows that the adsorbed NO species were detected at the same wavenumber (cm−1) in Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 3.5) and Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 1.7) catalysts. However, a relatively minute NO adsorption peak was detected in the Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 1.7) catalyst. The changes of NO adsorption peaks over time were examined. Fig. 7 (a) shows that the growth of NO adsorption peaks was detected after 40 s of NO injection in Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 3.5) catalyst. Fig. 7 (b) shows that NO adsorption peaks were detected after 120 s of NO injection in the Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 1.7) catalyst. In addition, as a result of comparing the adsorption peak with the other NO adsorption peaks based on 1540 cm−1, the ratio (each peak intensity/1540 cm−1 intensity) was decreased in the Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH1.7) catalyst compared to the Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 3.5) catalyst. From these results, it can be confirmed that the pH control suppresses the formation of NO adsorbed species on the Mn/Ce/W/ Ti catalyst surface. According to previous studies, NO adsorbates on the surface of Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts have been reported to exhibit relatively low activity compared to NH3 adsorbates. In particular, the results of previous studies indicate that NH3 adsorption sites and NO adsorption sites are shared in Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst [41]. Thus, pH control is thought to cause the increases in adsorption of NH3 by inhibiting NO adsorption on the adsorption site on the surface of catalyst. 3.2.3 Oxygen mobility characterization The main factors of the SCR reaction are the redox function of the catalyst, and the acid characteristics of the catalyst. In particular, the redox function plays an important role in the low temperature region, where the activation energy is low. These redox functions are known to proceed by NH3 injected as a reducing agent, lattice oxygen of the catalyst, and atmospheric oxygen [45,46]. In particular, the increase in oxygen mobility is thought to affect the activity promotion by increasing the re-oxidation rate of the active metals on the surface of catalyst reduced by the SCR reaction. Fig. 4 and Table 2 show that as the pH of the catalyst is controlled, the lattice oxygen (Oα) existing on the surface of catalyst is decreased, while the oxygen species (Oβ) corresponding to the surface chemisorption species is increased. Therefore, in this section, O2 chemisorption experiment was carried out, to examine the effect of the change of oxygen species existing on the surface of the catalyst on the oxygen mobility of the catalyst at the corresponding reaction temperatures. In this experiment, Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 3.5) and Mn/Ce/W/Ti (pH 1.7) catalysts were first treated with 10% H2/N2 for 30 min at 160 °C. After the available oxygen species was consumed at the corresponding temperature (160 °C) through the above pretreatment, and thus O2 bonding was formed on the surface of catalyst, oxygen was injected at constant concentration (500 ppm O2/N2) through a pulse way, and the O2 uptake of each catalyst was measured. Fig. 8 shows the results, which reveal that the O2 uptake in the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst whose pH was controlled was increased significantly from 1.141 × 10−3 mmol/g to 1.496 × 10-2 mmol/g. At the experimental temperature (160 °C), it was confirmed that the amount of surface adsorbed oxygen (Oβ) consumed in the catalytic reaction, and the amount of oxygen that can be stored in the catalyst during the re-oxidation process, were increased. From these results, it can be seen that oxygen species that can move at the reaction temperature (160 °C) increase, in other words, Oxygen mobility increases. The increase of oxygen mobility increases the redox characteristics of the catalysts, and in particular, it increases the re-oxidation rate of the active metals on the surface of the reduced catalysts. As a result, the SCR reaction activity is promoted. 4 Conclusions This study was conducted to examine the effects of pH control on the process of the preparation of Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst in low-temperature SCR through surface adsorption characteristics, and to characterize the catalysts, using their oxygen transport capacity. The results are as follows: When the slurry pH is controlled to low levels (acidic condition; ∼ pH 1.7) in the preparation of Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst, NH3 adsorption is promoted, while the formation of adsorbed NO species that is unfavorable to the SCR reaction is suppressed. In addition, the metal valence state of the surface of the catalyst promotes Mn4+ species that is favorable to the SCR reaction, and promotes the nonstoichiometric Ce3+ species. In particular, it is found that the Ce3+ species increases the adsorption oxygen species on the surface of catalyst, and increases the oxygen mobility, which has effects on the increases in the re-oxidation rate of the catalyst. As a result, it may cause the promotion of the low-temperature SCR reaction activity. Therefore, the pH change of the catalyst exhibits excellent low-temperature SCR reaction activity, due to the above-mentioned promotion of the adsorption characteristics of the surface of catalyst, and the enhancement of surface oxygen mobility. In particular, according to the literature, Ce3+ species increase the adsorption oxygen species on the surface of the catalyst and increase the oxygen mobility, which affects the increase of the catalyst's re-oxidation rate, thereby increasing the low temperature activity. Therefore, it is considered that the pH change of the catalyst increases the Ce3+ ratio and promotes the low temperature SCR reaction activity due to the enhancement of adsorption characteristics and oxygen mobility. coredata.dc:description: The purpose of this study is to investigate the effects of pH control on the oxidation state and oxygen storage capacity of catalysts, and the correlation with low-temperature selective catalytic reduction (SCR) activities using Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts. The activity of the catalysts showed increases in low-temperature SCR reaction activity at (120–180) °C, when the pH of the slurry of active metal and support TiO2 was controlled to low levels during the preparation of Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts. To characterize these catalysts, NH3-TPD, FT-IR DRIFT, XPS, and O2-chemisorption were analyzed. In the DRIFT experiment using FT-IR, the NH3 adsorption on acid sites of the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts, which exhibited excellent reaction activity in the SCR reaction, was increased, compared with those of the Mn/Ce/Ti catalysts. In particular, the NH4 + adsorbed on Brønsted acid site was greatly increased. When the adsorbed NH3 was reacted with injected NO + O2, the adsorbed NH3 species was rapidly decreased on Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts whose pH was controlled to low levels, and the reaction rate was greatly increased. According to XPS analysis, the increase of the O2 storage capacity of the catalyst is due to the decrease of the lattice oxygen present on the surface, and the increase of adsorbed oxygen species as the nonstoichiometric species Ce3+ increases. In addition, the O2-chemisorption showed that oxygen mobility was increased in the catalysts whose pH was controlled to low levels. These results indicate that oxygen mobility was increased due to the increases in the adsorbed oxygen species, which was found by XPS analysis. Therefore, the control of pH in the preparation of Mn catalyst increases the Brønsted acid site on the catalyst surface and increases oxygen mobility, due to the increase of adsorbed oxygen species, resulting in an increase in the SCR activity.
coredata.dc:title: Enhancement of Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts through control of pH and oxygen mobility during their preparation
